name: Financial and Market Objectives
what: This subtopic covers the objectives of making a profit, increasing market share and fulfilling a market need, as well as the SMART principle for setting effective objectives and the role of vision, mission and values statements.
why: Financial and market objectives drive strategic decisions in business. Understanding how to set, apply and evaluate these objectives is essential for analysing real and simulated business scenarios.

items.title: I can explain the SMART principle and evaluate whether objectives meet the SMART criteria
items.what: SMART objectives are Specific, Measurable, Attainable/Achievable, Realistic/Relevant, and Timely/Time-bound. This framework ensures objectives are clear and actionable.
items.why: Setting SMART objectives gives a business clear targets and a way to measure progress, which is critical for strategic planning.
items.example: A sole trader who aims to 'increase revenue by 15% within the next 12 months by expanding online sales' meets the SMART criteria. An objective to 'do better next year' does not, because it is not specific or measurable.

items.title: I can distinguish between vision statements, mission statements and values statements
items.what: A vision statement outlines what the business aspires to be in the future. A mission statement defines what the business wants to achieve now. A values statement outlines the organisation's corporate values, centring on integrity, honesty and ethical behaviour.
items.why: These statements provide the overarching direction from which specific business objectives are developed and aligned.
items.example: Virgin Australia's vision is 'to revolutionise air travel again, this time across all market segments'. Its mission focuses on providing seamless experiences across domestic and international markets.

items.title: I can define profit and explain why making a profit is a primary business objective
items.what: Profit is the difference between revenue and expenses. It is considered the lifeblood of a business because it ensures survival, enables growth and expansion, and meets investor expectations. One strategy to increase profit is reducing operational costs.
items.why: Profit is the most fundamental financial objective. Without profit, a private sector business cannot sustain its operations in the long term.
items.example: A retail business with $500,000 in revenue and $420,000 in expenses makes a profit of $80,000. It could increase profit by negotiating lower supplier costs to reduce expenses to $400,000, raising profit to $100,000.

items.title: I can define market share and explain strategies to increase it
items.what: Market share is the proportion or percentage of total sales in a market controlled by a business. Increasing market share means gaining a greater percentage of sales relative to competitors, resulting in increased revenue.
items.why: Higher market share often translates to greater revenue, stronger brand recognition and more influence within an industry.
items.example: Twins Pantry targets a niche in the gourmet nut market by offering dairy-free, preservative-free products at farmers' markets, using roasting aromas and free tastings to attract customers and grow their market share.

items.title: I can explain the objective of fulfilling a market need and apply it to business scenarios
items.what: Fulfilling a market need means recognising and satisfying the demands of actual or potential buyers. Markets can be physical (food, clothing, shelter), social (belonging, affection) or individual (knowledge, self-expression). A business must identify its market, assess its size and decide which segment to target.
items.why: A business that fails to meet a genuine market need is unlikely to generate sales or survive. Identifying gaps in the market is often the starting point for a successful business.
items.example: Bandicute identified a gap in children's clothing: most designs featured foreign animals like foxes and raccoons. By creating clothing featuring Australian animals, they fulfilled a previously unmet market need for Australian-themed kids' clothing.
